survey-consent.title:
Consent for a Child’s Participation in a Study for Educational Purposes Only 
 Let's Learn About Animals!

items.text:
Dear Parents,

We are inviting your child to participate in a study as part of training MIT undergraduate students in a course on infant and child development. The vast majority of studies posted on Children Helping Science are for research purposes. Studies purely for educational purposes constitute a tiny minority of studies on the platform <1%. However, this particular study will be used only for training students. The results of the study will not be published anywhere.

This study looks at how children learn concepts and categories. In this study, we show your child a video explaining a category of animals, show a few examples of animals in the category, and test their understanding of the category.

All parts of the experiment will be recorded, but no videos will be downloaded and all videos will be available for viewing only to the students, faculty, and teaching assistants in the class for the duration of the class and will be deleted by December 20th, 2024.

I understand that participation in this study is entirely voluntary, and if I decide that I do not want my child to take part, they can stop taking part in this study at any time without giving a reason.

If you have questions about the details of the study, you can contact shengyiw@mit.edu. If you have any additional questions, you can contact the faculty member teaching the class, Laura Schulz at lschulz@mit.edu.
I am this child’s parent or legal guardian and I give my permission for the child to participate in this study

blocks.title: Overview of what will happen in this study

listblocks.text: There will be three phases of each trial: definition, examples, and testing.
First, we will define an animal category (e.g. dog). Please make sure your child is paying attention to the video.

Next, we will show a screen with many animals. Point out the highlighted examples to your child. For example, (pointing to a poodle) 'This is a poodle. A poodle is a dog.' Only point out these three animals.

Lastly, we’ll ask your child if a specific animal is in the category. Your child should responding verbally. For this section, please sit outside of your child’s direct line of sight and try not to influence their answer.

blocks.text: Please try playing this sample audio to make sure you'll be able to hear the story.
blocks.title: Adjust your speakers

mediaBlock.warningText: Please try playing the sample audio.

webcamBlocks.title: Make sure we can see you

listblocks.text: Take a look at your webcam view above. Get comfy, and adjust your own position or the computer as needed so both you and your child are visible.

This isn't a Skype call - no one in the lab can see you - but the recorded video of your participation will be sent to the lab to help with data analysis. It's helpful for us to be able to see if your child was pointing or looking confused, for example.

debriefing.text:
Thank you so much for participating in this study 
This study was motivated by this paper by Tenembaum and Xu: https://web.mit.edu/cocosci/archive/Papers/cogsci00_FINAL.pdf . They showed that both adults and children use examples shown to gauge how broad the concept is. Thus, there are better and worse sets example to show to teach a concept. For example, showing three images of dalmatians is a terrible way to explain what a ‘dog’ is because these examples will make someone think that all dogs have black and white spots. Instead, a more representative set of examples would be a poodle, a golden retriever, and a husky. 
In this study, we wanted to know if parents could recognize this and go out of their way to turn a “bad” set of examples into a “better” one to help their children learn a concept. When analyzing this study, we will measure whether the parent (you) chose to point out non-highlighted animals of the category during the teaching phase of the trial. 
Thank you again for participating! We'll be emailing you a $5 Amazon gift card - this should arrive in your inbox within the next week after we confirm that a child is with you in the video recording and check that your child is in the age range for this study. If you don't hear from us by then, feel free to reach out! Please don’t hesitate to contact me at shengyiw@mit.edu if you have any additional questions or feedback!
